<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	18. Subsequent Events
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	preparing the consolidated financial statements, management has evaluated all subsequent events and transactions for potential recognition or disclosure through the date the accompanying consolidated financial statements were issued.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	19. Reorganization
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the planned
	reorganization, a new corporate entity was formed, Lonestar Resources U.S. Inc., which immediately prior to the reorganization will acquire the Parent via an Australian Scheme of Arrangement. As a result, certain accounting policies have been
	adopted in these financial statements as if the Company were a public company. These include earnings per share, segment reporting and supplemental oil and gas disclosures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-46
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage190"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D271827DS1A_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	GLOSSARY OF OIL AND NATURAL GAS TERMS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The terms defined in this section are used throughout this prospectus:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	3-D seismic
</I>
	.&#148; Geophysical data that depict the subsurface strata in three dimensions. 3-D seismic typically provides a more detailed and
	accurate interpretation of the subsurface strata than 2-D, or two-dimensional, seismic.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Basin
</I>
	.&#148; A large natural depression on the
	earth&#146;s surface in which sediments generally brought by water accumulate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Bbl
</I>
	.&#148; One stock tank barrel, of 42 U.S. gallons liquid
	volume, used in reference to crude oil, condensate or natural gas liquids.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Bbl/d
</I>
	.&#148; One stock tank barrel of crude oil, condensate or
	natural gas liquids pr day.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Boe
</I>
	.&#148; One barrel of oil equivalent, with 6,000 cubic feet of natural gas being equivalent to one barrel of
	oil.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Boe/d
</I>
	.&#148; One barrel of oil equivalent per day.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	British thermal unit
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	Btu
</I>
	.&#148; The heat required to raise the temperature of a one-pound mass of water from 58.5 to 59.5
	degrees Fahrenheit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	completion
</I>
	.&#148; The process of treating a drilled well followed by the installation of permanent equipment for the
	production of oil or natural gas, or in the case of a dry well, the reporting of abandonment to the appropriate agency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	condensate
</I>
	.&#148; A
	mixture of hydrocarbons that exists in the gaseous phase at original reservoir temperature and pressure, but that, when produced, is in the liquid phase at surface pressure and temperature.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	developed acreage
</I>
	.&#148; The number of acres that are allocated or assignable to productive wells or wells capable of production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	development capital
</I>
	.&#148; Expenditures to obtain access to proved reserves and to construct facilities for producing, treating and storing
	hydrocarbons.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	development well
</I>
	.&#148; A well drilled within the proved area of an oil or natural gas reservoir to the depth of a
	stratigraphic horizon known to be productive.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	downspacing
</I>
	.&#148; Additional wells drilled between known producing wells to better exploit
	the reservoir.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	dry well
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;dry.&#148; A well found to be incapable of producing hydrocarbons in sufficient quantities such that
	proceeds from the sale of such production exceed production expenses and taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	economically producible
</I>
	.&#148; A resource that generates
	revenue that exceeds, or is reasonably expected to exceed, the costs of the operation. For a complete definition of economically producible, refer to the SEC&#146;s Regulation
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	S-X,
</FONT>
	Rule 4-10(a)(10).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	exploitation
</I>
	.&#148; A development or other project which may target proven or unproven reserves (such as probable or possible reserves), but
	which generally has a lower risk than that associated with exploration projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	exploratory well
</I>
	.&#148; A well drilled to find a new field
	or to find a new reservoir in a field previously found to be productive of oil or natural gas in another reservoir.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	G-1
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage191"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D271827DS1A_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	field
</I>
	.&#148; An area consisting of a single reservoir or multiple reservoirs all grouped on or
	related to the same individual geological structural feature and/or stratigraphic condition. The field name refers to the surface area, although it may refer to both the surface and the underground productive formations. For a complete definition of
	field, refer to the SEC&#146;s Regulation S-X, Rule 4-10(a)(15).
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_79"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	formation
</I>
	.&#148; A layer of rock which has distinct characteristics that
	differ from nearby rock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	GAAP
</I>
	.&#148; Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	gross acres
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	gross wells
</I>
	.&#148; The total acres or wells, as the case may be, in which an entity owns a working interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	held by production
</I>
	.&#148; Acreage covered by a mineral lease that perpetuates a company&#146;s right to operate a property as long as the
	property produces a minimum paying quantity of oil or gas.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	horizontal drilling
</I>
	.&#148; A drilling technique used in certain formations where
	a well is drilled vertically to a certain depth and then drilled at a right angle within a specified interval.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	IRS.
</I>
	&#148; Internal Revenue
	Service.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	lease operating expense
</I>
	.&#148; All direct and allocated indirect costs of lifting hydrocarbons from a producing formation to the
	surface constituting part of the current operating expenses of a working interest. Such costs include labor, superintendence, supplies, repairs, maintenance, allocated overhead charges, workover, insurance and other expenses incidental to
	production, but exclude lease acquisition or drilling or completion expenses.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_80"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	LIBOR
</I>
	.&#148; London Interbank Offered Rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MBbl
</I>
	.&#148; One thousand barrels of crude oil, condensate or NGLs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MBoe
</I>
	.&#148; One thousand barrels of oil equivalent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Mcf
</I>
	.&#148; One thousand cubic feet of natural gas.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	Mcf/d
</I>
	.&#148; One thousand cubic feet of natural gas per day.
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MMBbls
</I>
	.&#148; One million stock tank barrels, of 42 U.S. gallons liquid volume, used in reference to crude oil, condensate or natural gas
	liquids.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_81"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MMBoe
</I>
	.&#148; One million barrels of oil equivalent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MMBtu
</I>
	.&#148; One million British thermal units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	MMcf
</I>
	.&#148; One million cubic feet of natural gas.
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	natural gas liquids
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	NGLs
</I>
	.&#148; The combination of ethane, propane, butane, isobutane and natural gasolines that when
	removed from natural gas become liquid under various levels of higher pressure and lower temperature.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	net acres
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	net
	wells
</I>
	.&#148; The percentage of total acres or wells, as the case may be, an owner has out of a particular number of gross acres or wells. For example, an owner who has 50% interest in 100 gross acres owns 50 net acres.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	net revenue interest
</I>
	.&#148; An owner&#146;s interest in the revenues of a well after deducting proceeds allocated to royalty and overriding
	interests.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	G-2
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage192"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D271827DS1A_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	NYMEX
</I>
	.&#148; The New York Mercantile Exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	operator
</I>
	.&#148; The entity responsible for the exploration, development and production of a well or lease.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	present value of future net revenues
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	PV-10
</I>
	.&#148; The estimated future gross revenue to be generated from the production of
	proved reserves, net of estimated production and future development and abandonment costs, using prices and costs in effect at the determination date, before income taxes, and without giving effect to non-property-related expenses, discounted to a
	present value using an annual discount rate of 10% in accordance with the guidelines of the SEC.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	productive well
</I>
	.&#148; A well that is found
	to be capable of producing hydrocarbons in sufficient quantities such that proceeds from the sale of the production exceed production expenses and taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	proved developed reserves
</I>
	.&#148; Proved reserves that can be expected to be recovered:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	i. Through existing wells with existing equipment and operating methods or in which the cost of the required equipment is relatively minor compared with the
	cost of a new well; or
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	ii. Through installed extraction equipment and infrastructure operational at the time of the reserves estimate if the extraction
	is by means not involving a well.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	proved reserves
</I>
	.&#148; Those quantities of oil and natural gas, which, by analysis of geoscience and
	engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government
	regulations&nbsp;&#151;prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the
	estimation. The project to extract the hydrocarbons must have commenced, or the operator must be reasonably certain that it will commence, the project within a reasonable time. For a complete definition of proved oil and natural gas reserves, refer
	to the SEC&#146;s Regulation S-X, Rule 4-10(a)(22).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	proved undeveloped reserves
</I>
	&#148; or &#147;
<I>
	PUDs
</I>
	.&#148; Proved reserves that are
	expected to be recovered from new wells on undrilled acreage, or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required for recompletion.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Reserves on undrilled acreage shall be limited to those directly offsetting development spacing areas that are reasonably certain of production when drilled,
	unless evidence using reliable technology exists that establishes reasonable certainty of economic producibility at greater distances.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Undrilled
	locations can be classified as having undeveloped reserves only if a development plan has been adopted indicating that they are scheduled to be drilled within five years, unless the specific circumstances justify a longer time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under no circumstances shall estimates for proved undeveloped reserves be attributable to any acreage for which an application of fluid injection or other
	improved recovery technique is contemplated, unless such techniques have been proved effective by actual projects in the same reservoir or an analogous reservoir, or by other evidence using reliable technology establishing reasonable certainty.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	reasonable certainty
</I>
	.&#148; A high degree of confidence. For a complete definition of reasonable certainty, refer to the SEC&#146;s Regulation
	S-X, Rule 4-10(a)(24).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	recompletion
</I>
	.&#148; The process of re-entering an existing wellbore that is either producing or not producing and
	completing new reservoirs in an attempt to establish or increase existing production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	G-3
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage193"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D271827DS1A_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	reliable technology
</I>
	.&#148; A grouping of one or more technologies (including computational methods)
	that have been field tested and have been demonstrated to provide reasonably certain results with consistency and repeatability in the formation being evaluated or in an analogous formation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	reserves.
</I>
	&#148; Estimated remaining quantities of oil and natural gas and related substances anticipated to be economically producible, as of a
	given date, by application of development prospects to known accumulations. In addition, there must exist, or there must be a reasonable expectation that there will exist, the legal right to produce or a revenue interest in the production, installed
	means of delivering oil and natural gas or related substances to market and all permits and financing required to implement the project.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	reservoir.
</I>
	&#148; A porous and permeable underground formation containing a natural accumulation of producible hydrocarbons that is confined by
	impermeable rock or water barriers and is separate from other reservoirs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	royalty.
</I>
	&#148; An interest in an oil and natural gas lease that
	gives the owner the right to receive a portion of the production from the leased acreage (or of the proceeds from the sale thereof), but does not require the owner to pay any portion of the production or development costs on the leased acreage.
	Royalties may be either landowner&#146;s royalties, which are reserved by the owner of the leased acreage at the time the lease is granted, or overriding royalties, which are usually reserved by an owner of the leasehold in connection with a
	transfer to a subsequent owner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	SEC.
</I>
	&#148; The United States Securities and Exchange Commission.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	spacing.
</I>
	&#148; The distance between wells producing from the same reservoir. Spacing is often expressed in terms of acres, e.g., 40-acre spacing,
	and is often established by regulatory agencies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	spud
</I>
	.&#148; Commenced drilling operations on an identified location.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	undeveloped acreage.
</I>
	&#148; Lease acreage on which wells have not been drilled or completed to a point that would permit the production of
	economic quantities of oil or natural gas regardless of whether such acreage contains proved reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	wellbore.
</I>
	&#148; The hole drilled by
	the bit that is equipped for oil or gas production on a completed well. Also called well or borehole.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	working interest.
</I>
	&#148; The right
	granted to the lessee of a property to explore for and to produce and own oil, natural gas or other minerals. The working interest owners bear the exploration, development and operating costs on either a cash, penalty or carried basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	workover.
</I>
	&#148; Operations on a producing well to restore or increase production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#147;
<I>
	WTI.
</I>
	&#148; West Texas Intermediate crude oil, which is a light, sweet crude oil, characterized by an American Petroleum Institute gravity, or API
	gravity, between 39 and 41 and a sulfur content of approximately 0.4 weight percent that is used as a benchmark for other crude oils.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	G-4
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage194"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:14PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

</B>
</P>

</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:30PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

</I>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:30PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:30PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:30PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Dealer Prospectus Delivery Obligation
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Until &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (25 days after commencement of this offering), all dealers that
	effect transactions in these securities, whether or not participating in this offering, may be required to deliver a prospectus. This is in addition to the dealer&#146;s obligation to deliver a prospectus when acting as an underwriter and with
	respect to unsold allotments or subscriptions.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:30PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:4.5PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<EFX_INDEMNIFICATION>
<A NAME="FIS_INDEMNIFICATION"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	ITEM 14. INDEMNIFICATION OF DIRECTORS AND OFFICERS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Section&nbsp;145 of the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware (the &#147;DGCL&#148;) permits a Delaware corporation to indemnify its
	officers, directors and other corporate agents to the extent and under the circumstances set forth therein. Our Certificate of Incorporation (the &#147;certificate of incorporation&#148;) and Bylaws (the &#147;bylaws&#148;) provide that we will
	indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative or investigative, by reason of the fact that he is or was our
	director or officer or board observer, or is or was serving at our request as a director, officer, employee or agent of another corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust or other enterprise, in accordance with provisions corresponding to
	Section&nbsp;145 of the DGCL. These indemnification provisions may be sufficiently broad to permit indemnification of our executive officers and directors for liabilities, including reimbursement of expenses incurred, arising under the Securities
	Act.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to Section&nbsp;102(b)(7) of the DGCL, our certificate of incorporation will eliminate the personal liability of a director
	to us or our stockholders for monetary damages for a breach of fiduciary duty as a director, except for liability:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	for any breach of the director&#146;s duty of loyalty to us or our stockholders;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	for acts or omissions not in good faith or which involve intentional misconduct or a knowing violation of law;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	under Section&nbsp;174 of the DGCL (or any successor provision thereto); and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	for any transaction from which the director derived any improper personal benefit.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The above
	discussion of Section&nbsp;145 of the DGCL and of our certificate of incorporation and bylaws is not intended to be exhaustive and is respectively qualified in its entirety by Section&nbsp;145 of the DGCL, our certificate of incorporation and
	bylaws.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As permitted by Section&nbsp;145 of the DGCL, we carry primary and excess insurance policies insuring our directors and officers
	against certain liabilities they may incur in their capacity as directors and officers. Under the policies, the insurer, on our behalf, may also pay amounts for which we granted indemnification to our directors and officers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, the underwriting agreement to be filed as Exhibit&nbsp;1.1 to this Registration Statement provides that the underwriters will
	indemnify us and our executive officers and directors for certain liabilities related to this offering, including liabilities arising under the Securities Act.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	II-1
</P>

</EFX_INDEMNIFICATION>
<EFX_SALE_OF_UNREGISTERED_SECURITIES>
<A NAME="FIS_SALE_OF_UNREGISTERED_SECURITIES"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	ITEM 15. RECENT SALES OF UNREGISTERED SECURITIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the past three years, we have issued unregistered securities to a limited number of persons as described below. We believe that each of
	these transactions was exempt from the registration requirement pursuant to Section (4)(a)(2) available under the Securities Act.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July
	5, 2016, the Company acquired all of the issued and outstanding ordinary shares of Lonestar Resources Limited (the &#147;Predecessor&#148;) as part of a reorganization (&#147;the Reorganization&#148;) and pursuant to a scheme of arrangement under
	Australian law. The Company issued to the stockholders of the Predecessor one share of Class A common stock for every two ordinary shares of the Predecessor that were issued and outstanding.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the Reorganization, the company adopted the Lonestar Resources US Inc. 2016 Incentive Plan (the &#147;2016 Plan&#148;) to
	replace the existing incentive plans of the Predecessor. Options issued under the prior incentive plans were cancelled and replaced with option awards under the 2016 Plan for 1,027,941 shares of the Company&#146;s Class A common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The issuances of shares and options in connection with the Reorganization were made in reliance of the exemption from registration under
	Section 3(a)(10) of the Securities Act.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;2, 2016, LRAI and the Company entered into a Securities Purchase Agreement (the
	&#147;Purchase Agreement&#148;) with Juneau, as initial purchaser, Leucadia, as guarantor of Juneau&#146;s obligations, the other purchasers party thereto and Jefferies, LLC, in its capacity as the collateral agent for the purchasers, relating to
	the issuance and sale of (i)&nbsp;up to $49,900,000 aggregate principal amount of LRAI&#146;s 12% senior secured second lien notes due 2021 (the &#147;Notes&#148;) and (ii)&nbsp;five-year warrants to purchase up to an aggregate 998,000 shares of the
	Company&#146;s Class A common stock at a price equal to $5.00 per share (the &#147;Warrants&#148;).&nbsp;Pursuant to the Purchase Agreement, LRAI has issued $38 million aggregate principal worth of Notes at par and the Company has issued Warrants
	for the purchase of 760,000 shares of Class A common stock. The date and amount of each issuance is detailed below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August 2, 2016, the Company entered into a purchase and sale agreement with Juneau pursuant to which the
	Company issued 500,227 shares of Class A common stock in exchange for an undivided 50% interest in two producing wells and each well&#146;s respective&nbsp;oil and gas leases covering approximately 1,300 net mineral acres located in Brazos County,
	Texas.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The issuances of Class A common stock pursuant to the Purchase Agreement were made in reliance of the exemption from registration
	under Section 4(a)(2) of the Securities Act.
</P>

<EFX_UNDERTAKINGS>
<A NAME="FIS_UNDERTAKINGS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	ITEM 17. UNDERTAKINGS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The undersigned Registrant hereby undertakes to provide to the underwriters at the closing specified in the underwriting agreement certificates
	in such denominations and registered in such names as required by the underwriters to permit prompt delivery to each purchaser.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Insofar
	as indemnification for liabilities arising under the Securities Act may be permitted to directors, officers and controlling persons of the Registrant pursuant to the provisions described in Item&nbsp;14 above, or otherwise, the Registrant has been
	advised that in the opinion of the Securities and Exchange Commission such indemnification is against public policy as expressed in the Securities Act and is, therefore, unenforceable. In the event that a claim for indemnification against such
	liabilities (other than the payment by the Registrant of expenses incurred or paid by a director, officer or controlling person of the Registrant in the successful defense of any action, suit or proceeding) is asserted by such director, officer or
	controlling person in connection with the securities being registered, the Registrant will, unless in the opinion of its counsel the matter has been settled by controlling precedent, submit to a court of appropriate jurisdiction the question whether
	such indemnification by it is against public policy as expressed in the Securities Act and will be governed by the final adjudication of such issue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The undersigned registrant hereby undertakes that:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(1) For purposes of determining any liability under the Securities Act, the information omitted from the form of prospectus filed as part of
	this Registration Statement in reliance upon Rule 430A and contained in a form of prospectus filed by the Registrant pursuant to Rule 424(b)(1) or (4)&nbsp;or 497(h) under the Securities Act shall be deemed to be part of this Registration Statement
	as of the time it was declared effective; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(2) For the purpose of determining any liability under the Securities Act, each
	post-effective amendment that contains a form of prospectus shall be deemed to be a new registration statement relating to the securities offered therein, and the offering of such securities at the time shall be deemed to be the initial bona fide
	offering thereof.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	II-3
</P>

</U>

	We hereby consent to the use in this registration statement on Form&nbsp;S-1, including any amendments thereto, related appendices, exhibits and financial
	statements (the &#147;Registration Statement&#148;), for Lonestar Resources US Inc. of information from, and the inclusion of, our reports dated February 22, 2016, January&nbsp;29, 2015 and March&nbsp;22, 2014, with respect to estimates of reserves
	and future cash flows of Lonestar Resources,&nbsp;Inc. as of December 31, 2015, December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013, respectively.
</P>

	further consent to all references to our firm as experts in the Registration Statement.
